elements.content: The polymorphism in the copper­(II) alkanoates, recently discovered for one member, has been thoroughly studied for the whole series, from 3 to 16 C atoms. Three polymorphic phases have been found, all of them sharing the same molecular unit, the paddle-wheel, which grows forming a 1D coordination polymer or catena. The three polymorphs are defined by a different packing of these catenae and a specific arrangement of the alkyl chains. Ten new crystal structures of those compounds have been solved by high resolution powder diffraction and presented in this paper. The polymorphism in this series has been found to be monotropic and is responsible for the complex thermal behavior observed. The most characteristic feature, the endothermic–exothermic effect, has been explained for the first time in these compounds by a combination of data from differential scanning calorimetry (in normal and modulated modes), powder X-ray diffraction and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy. These techniques, together with small-angle X-ray scattering and optical microscopy, were used to analyze the hexagonal columnar discotic liquid crystal phase of copper­(II) alkanoates. Thus, new information has been found in the packing and stacking of the discs formed by the paddle-wheel units, also maintained in the mesophase.

elements.content: The three polymorphic phases of copper­(II) alkanoates, as well as their columnar discotic liquid crystal phase, were studied by XRD, DSC, FTIR, SAXS, and optical microscopy, explaining the very intricate thermal behavior and the monotropic nature of this polymorphism.

elements.content: Copper­(II) alkanoates have been studied for a long time by a number of authors, using a great variety of techniques (DCS, DTA, FTIR, Raman, and NMR spectroscopies, dilatometry, conductance, EXAFS, and single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction). Moreover, there are several reviews discussing general aspects of the copper­(II) alkanoate series. Among them, the ones on metal-containing liquid crystals by Guiroud-Godquin, Donnio, or Polishchuk et al. are very interesting. In another important article, by Mrovzinski, a molecular magnetism study on copper alkanoates has been carried out oriented to modeling electrical, magnetic, and optical properties in this family of compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Copper(II) alkanoates have been studied for a long time by a number of authors, using a great variety of techniques (DCS, DTA, FTIR, Raman, and NMR spectroscopies, dilatometry, conductance, EXAFS, and single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction). Moreover, there are several reviews discussing general aspects of the copper(II) alkanoate series. Among them, the ones on metal-containing liquid crystals by Guiroud-Godquin, Donnio, or Polishchuk et al. are very interesting. In another important article, by Mrovzinski, a molecular magnetism study on copper alkanoates has been carried out oriented to modeling electrical, magnetic, and optical properties in this family of compounds.

elements.content: Besides their behavior as surfactants because of their amphiphilic nature, their interest could be summarized as follows: (1) they are mesogens of columnar discotic liquid crystals (CDLCs), (2) they form adducts as a consequence of the particular coordination of the copper­(II) ion, (3) they are precursors of structures of organometallic compounds with biological or pharmaceutical applications, and (4) they can be used as templates or nanoreactors in the synthesis of Cu and CuO nanoparticles of different shape, etc.
elements.clean_text: Besides their behavior as surfactants because of their amphiphilic nature, their interest could be summarized as follows: (1) they are mesogens of columnar discotic liquid crystals (CDLCs), (2) they form adducts as a consequence of the particular coordination of the copper(II) ion, (3) they are precursors of structures of organometallic compounds with biological or pharmaceutical applications, and (4) they can be used as templates or nanoreactors in the synthesis of Cu and CuO nanoparticles of different shape, etc.

elements.content: Most of the metal soaps (or alkanoates; Me­(Cn) x from now on, where Me is the metallic cation (+x) and n is the total number of C atoms of the carboxylate) are crystalline 2D coordination polymers in the crystal phase, showing a bilayered arrangement: an ionic layer (formed by the metal cations and the carboxylate anions) and a lipidic layer (van der Waals interactions between the −CH3 chain ends). However, copper­(II) alkanoates, as well as rhodium­(II) and ruthenium­(II) alkanoates, present a different arrangement, even when they maintain a similar bilayer structure, at least in most of their polymorphs. They present binuclear units, formed by the copper­(II) and carboxylate ions, and are designated in the literature as Chinese lanterns or more recently paddle-wheels, which can be represented as discs (see Figure a). These units are coordinated (a double Cu···O–Cu···O coordination bond) forming a catena (Figure b), which is a 1D coordination polymer. These fiber-like catenae are attracted one to another by van der Waals forces. A very recent study on the copper­(II) decanoate–decanoic acid phase diagram has allowed the discovery of a new polymorph of the copper­(II) salt and helped to relate it to the other polymorphs, based on the different stacking of these catenae.

These fiber-like catenae are attracted one to another by van der Waals forces. A very recent study on the copper(II) decanoate-decanoic acid phase diagram has allowed the discovery of a new polymorph of the copper(II) salt and helped to relate it to the other polymorphs, based on the different stacking of these catenae.

elements.content: Three different polymorphs have been discovered so far for the members of the copper­(II) alkanoate series (A, B, and C). The three of them present the same molecular units, paddle-wheel catenae, the main difference being the packing of these catenae, apart from the different orientation of the alkyl chains in the polymorphs. Thus, polymorphs A and C are bilayered (or lamellar), while B presents a two-by-two interdigitated alkyl chain structure. Polymorphs A and B show the same orientation for all the catenae and C presents two alternating catenae with opposite orientation (see Figure c).

Thus, polymorphs A and C are bilayered (or lamellar), while B presents a two-by-two interdigitated alkyl chain structure. Polymorphs A and B show the same orientation for all the catenae and C presents two alternating catenae with opposite orientation (see Figure c).

elements.content: However, as will be discussed later, not all the members present all of the polymorphic phases. Thus, polymorph A has been only observed in members with n ≤ 10, polymorph B in even number members with 8 ≤ n ≤ 14, and polymorph C in members with n ≥ 9. Thus, Cu­(C10)2 is the only member with three polymorphic phases, which are represented in Figure .

elements.content: Recently, selective formation of CuO and Cu­(OH)2 nanoparticles has been observed from lamellar and interdigitated polymorphs of Cu­(C10)2, respectively, proving the relevance of these polymorphic structures.
elements.clean_text: Recently, selective formation of CuO and Cu(OH)2 nanoparticles has been observed from lamellar and interdigitated polymorphs of Cu(C10)2, respectively, proving the relevance of these polymorphic structures.

elements.content: The thermal behavior of these compounds is very complicated and depends on the method for obtaining the samples. For instance, by recrystallization in different solvents or by cooling from the liquid crystal phase, mixtures of polymorphs or low-crystallinity effects may be obtained. In fact, an “endo–exo” effect is found in the thermograms, designated in the literature as premelting or oscillations for the last 35 years, which is here explained for the first time as structural relaxation (endo), followed by cold crystallization (exo). Moreover, the relationship between polymorphs is monotropic, so the metastable polymorphs melt (totally or partially) before converting into the corresponding stable polymorphs.

Moreover, the relationship between polymorphs is monotropic, so the metastable polymorphs melt (totally or partially) before converting into the corresponding stable polymorphs.

elements.content: The mesogenicity of these compounds has been widely studied and is very characteristic. The liquid crystal phase appears in members of the series with n ≥ 4. The structure of this phase, studied by XRD, is hexagonal columnar discotic liquid crystal (HCDLC or simply CDLC, here on), with the exception of Cu­(C4)2, which is tetragonal. The same paddle-wheel units (or discs) described above for the room temperature crystal are maintained in the CDLC phase, showing the same bond lengths (observed by EXAFS and PDF analysis). It has been proven that the discs in the CDLC phase are not tilted (again with the exception of Cu­(C4)2), in contrast to the crystal phase. Thus, the discs remain, as a core, forming the fiber-like 1D coordination polymer, and the alkyl chains are melted. This phase decomposes before the transition to isotropic liquid.

elements.content: In this work, a thermal, spectroscopic, and structural study was carried out for the members of the Cu­(Cn)2 series (up to Cu­(C16)2). We also report the structural characteristics of this series, explaining the monotropic polymorphism. The structures of the new polymorphic phases are also provided (10 new structures solved by XRD), and the relationship between them is discussed in depth, as well as the studies of the CDLC phase, using several techniques (such as DSC, X-ray scattering, FTIR and optical microscopy).

elements.content: Several methods have been employed to synthesize the different members of the Cu­(Cn)2 series, depending on the alkyl chain length of the ligands, which make the corresponding alkanoic acids soluble or insoluble. However, the recrystallization in different solvents clearly affects the formation of different polymorphs with 8 ≤ n ≤ 14.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Sample Preparation

Several methods have been employed to synthesize the different members of the Cu(Cn)2 series, depending on the alkyl chain length of the ligands, which make the corresponding alkanoic acids soluble or insoluble. However, the recrystallization in different solvents clearly affects the formation of different polymorphs with 8 ≤ n ≤ 14.

elements.content: A general method to obtain either short or long copper­(II) alkanoates consisted in the dropwise addition of alkanoic acid (Fluka, >99.0%) to a hot suspension of basic copper­(II) carbonate (Fluka, >95%) in excess, in absolute ethanol, to which some milliliters of deionized water is also added. After 2–4 days, when evolution of CO2 is no more apparent, the hot solution is filtered to remove the excess carbonate. Then, the solvent is evaporated to reduce its volume to one-half, the solution is allowed to cool to room temperature, and the flasks are kept for 2–3 days at 273 K, obtaining the first crystallization of the salts.
elements.clean_text: A general method to obtain either short or long copper(II) alkanoates consisted in the dropwise addition of alkanoic acid (Fluka, >99.0%) to a hot suspension of basic copper(II) carbonate (Fluka, >95%) in excess, in absolute ethanol, to which some milliliters of deionized water is also added. After 2-4 days, when evolution of CO2 is no more apparent, the hot solution is filtered to remove the excess carbonate. Then, the solvent is evaporated to reduce its volume to one-half, the solution is allowed to cool to room temperature, and the flasks are kept for 2-3 days at 273 K, obtaining the first crystallization of the salts.

elements.content: For members with n < 10, a specific method was used consisting of direct reaction between the corresponding organic acid and ground copper­(II) oxide suspended in hot ethanol (Fluka, > 99.8%), heating at reflux for several hours.
elements.clean_text: For members with n < 10, a specific method was used consisting of direct reaction between the corresponding organic acid and ground copper(II) oxide suspended in hot ethanol (Fluka, > 99.8%), heating at reflux for several hours.

elements.content:
One new method was used to synthesize members with n ≥ 9, consisting of the addition of CuCl2 (Aldrich, 99%) to a solution of the corresponding potassium or sodium alkanoate in deionized water.

In this second method, the samples were repeatedly washed with cold water and acetone. In the rest of the cases, a subsequent recrystallization was carried out using different solvents, such as heptane, ethanol, and benzene, among others. Their different polarity is responsible for the polymorph or mixture of polymorphs formed, as well as for the crystallinity of them. Since polymorph B of copper­(II) decanoate (Cu­(C10)2-B, from now on) had been obtained in ethanol and benzene, these two solvents were chosen in order to find this polymorph B in shorter and longer members of the series.

elements.content: Crystals suitable for single crystal XRD could be obtained by slow evaporation from ethanolic solutions (for members with n ≤ 10), although their single crystal quality decreased rapidly with the longer alkyl chains. For long members (n ≥ 10), a recent method was developed to obtain crystals: slow cooling of copper­(II) alkanoates dissolved in the corresponding alkanoic acid (HCn). In Table , the different polymorphs obtained by different methods and solvents used are summarized. In some cases, a mixture of polymorphs was formed, as in the cases of Cu­(C8)2 in benzene, Cu­(C9)2 in water, or cooling from the melt in the even members with n ≥ 8. Polymorphic phase C of Cu­(Cn)2 with n ≥ 9 was also obtained by a thermal treatment consisting of heating until the end temperature of the endo–exo effect. This method, explained later in the sample thermal behavior (section ), is the only one that allows us to obtain Cu­(C9)2-C.

elements.content: High resolution powder diffraction (HRPD) measurements were performed at SpLine beamline (BM25A) of the Spanish CRG at the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF, Grenoble) in two different experiments: (a) for Cu­(C9)2-A and Cu­(C11)-C and (b) for members from Cu­(C12)2 to Cu­(C16)2 (polymorphs C), with a fixed wavelength of 0.8266 and 0.7754 Å, respectively. All the measurements were carried out at room temperature. The powdered samples were placed inside a 0.7 mm diameter glass capillaries, which were rotated during exposure. Data collection was done in a 2θ-step scan mode with 0.015° step and 3–5 s acquisition time per point.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) and Small Angle X-ray Scattering (SAXS)

High resolution powder diffraction (HRPD) measurements were performed at SpLine beamline (BM25A) of the Spanish CRG at the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF, Grenoble) in two different experiments: (a) for Cu(C9)2-A and Cu(C11)-C and (b) for members from Cu(C12)2 to Cu(C16)2 (polymorphs C), with a fixed wavelength of 0.8266 and 0.7754 Å, respectively. All the measurements were carried out at room temperature. The powdered samples were placed inside a 0.7 mm diameter glass capillaries, which were rotated during exposure. Data collection was done in a 2θ-step scan mode with 0.015° step and 3-5 s acquisition time per point.

elements.content: Cu­(C9)2-C, Cu­(C10)2-A, and the mixture of polymorphs of Cu­(C8)2 (polymorphs A and B) were measured at room temperature in transmission mode in a Panalytical X’Pert PRO diffractometer equipped with a “hybrid monochromator” (a combination of a parabolic mirror and a Ge220 channel cut monochromator) and a fast RTMS detector X’Celerator (Cu Kα1 radiation, 1.54056 Å, 45 kV, 40 mA). The measurement ranges of 2θ were from 2° to 90° (for Cu­(C9)2 and Cu­(C10)2) and from 2° to 60° (for Cu­(C8)2) with a step size 0.017°. The samples were prepared in 0.5 mm diameter glass capillaries and rotated during exposure.

The measurement ranges of 2θ were from 2° to 90° (for Cu(C9)2 and Cu(C10)2) and from 2° to 60° (for Cu(C8)2) with a step size 0.017°. The samples were prepared in 0.5 mm diameter glass capillaries and rotated during exposure.

elements.content: SAXS measurements as a function of temperature were performed at the I911-4 SAXS beamline of the Swedish Synchrotron MAX IV Laboratory. The scattering vector q range analyzed was from 0.1 to 6.5 nm–1 (q = (4π/λ) sin­(θ), where λ = 0.91 Å and 2θ is the scattering angle). The sample–detector distance was calibrated with silver behenate. The data were collected in a bidimensional detector (PILATUS 1M, Dectris). A LINKAM hot stage model THMS600 was used to control the temperature of the sample. Data reduction was done using the software bli911-4.

elements.content: Routine XRD measurements as a function of temperature were carried out in reflection mode with a Panalytical X’Pert PRO MPD X-ray diffractometer with vertical goniometer θ/θ and RTMS X’Celerator detector equipped with a high-temperature camera Anton Paar HTK1200 (Cu Kα1 radiation, 1.54056 Å, 45 kV, 40 mA, Ni filter). In-situ XRPD scans were measured in inert atmosphere (N2(g)) from 2θ = 2°–40° at several temperatures in the range from 298 to 393 K during heating and cooling, after programming every temperature change at a rate of 3 K·min–1.

elements.content:
The Rietveld refinements and fitting were carried out using the FullProf program.

Differential Scanning Calorimetry

A TA Instruments modulated-DSC, model Q20, connected to an RCS cooling unit, was used in the normal mode to register all the thermograms at a heating rate of 5 K·min–1 (except those for the endo–exo effect study, where the heat-only mode was used), in the temperature range from 200 to 600 K. Tightly sealed aluminum volatile pans were used in dry nitrogen flowing at 50.0 mL·min–1.

elements.clean_text:
FTIR Spectroscopy

Infrared spectra of samples in KBr pellets were recorded using a PerkinElmer Spectrum100 FTIR spectrometer at a resolution of 2 cm-1. A commercial variable temperature cell, SPECAC VTL-2, adapted for solid samples, was employed to obtain IR spectra of the heated samples.

elements.content: The known structures, prior to the discovery of polymorphism in the Cu­(Cn)2 series, are isostructural and correspond to the members from Cu­(C3)2 to Cu­(C8)2 and Cu­(C10)2 (solved by Lomer et al., which presents some particularities that are discussed at the end of this paragraph). They all present the structure of polymorph A. Ten new structures have been solved in this work for medium and long members of the Cu­(Cn)2 series, from Cu­(C8)2 to Cu­(C16)2, including the three known polymorphic phases: A, B, and C. Thus, the structures of Cu­(C9)2-A and Cu­(C10)2-A, Cu­(C8)2-B, and Cu­(C9)2-C to Cu­(C16)2-C (with the exception of Cu­(C10)2, recently published) are presented here. All the crystallographic data and fittings obtained by Rietveld refinement are given in the , as well as the cif files.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Polymorphism: Polymorphs A, B, and C. Crystal Structures

The known structures, prior to the discovery of polymorphism in the Cu(Cn)2 series, are isostructural and correspond to the members from Cu(C3)2 to Cu(C8)2  and Cu(C10)2 (solved by Lomer et al., which presents some particularities that are discussed at the end of this paragraph). They all present the structure of polymorph A. Ten new structures have been solved in this work for medium and long members of the Cu(Cn)2 series, from Cu(C8)2 to Cu(C16)2, including the three known polymorphic phases: A, B, and C. Thus, the structures of Cu(C9)2-A and Cu(C10)2-A, Cu(C8)2-B, and Cu(C9)2-C to Cu(C16)2-C (with the exception of Cu(C10)2, recently published) are presented here. All the crystallographic data and fittings obtained by Rietveld refinement are given in the , as well as the cif files.

elements.content: A crystalline mixture of polymorphs (calculated to be A and B, in 75.0% and 25.0% in mass percent, respectively), obtained by recrystallization in benzene, was used to solve the structure of Cu­(C8)2-B. The mixture was refined by the Rietveld method, using the known structure of Cu­(C8)2-A and a model based in Cu­(C10)2-B (Figure ). The mixture was analyzed by SEM, and the different morphology of the crystals of both polymorphs was observed (see ).

elements.content: Cu­(C9)2-A was solved by single crystal XRD (see , for details) with poor statistics, due to poor quality of the crystals. However, the solution was used in the powder XRD measurements and properly solved by Rietveld refinement. This structure was also used as a model for Cu­(C10)2-A (obtained by recrystallization in heptane, with low crystallinity), which was refined using rigid body constraints for the alkyl chains. The structures of the polymorphic phase C for Cu­(C9)2 and Cu­(C11)2–Cu­(C16)2 were solved by simulated annealing (with the Fullprof program), using rigid body constraints for the alkyl chains, and refined by the Rietveld method (see ).

elements.content: The three polymorphs are centrosymmetric and present a common asymmetric unit, formed by one Cu atom and two carboxylates. These two carboxylates are different: one of them with all-trans conformation of the C atoms of the alkyl chain and another one with a gauche effect in the α carbon. The paddle-wheel shows two asymmetric units. There is one cell parameter that is similar in the three polymorphs, which corresponds to the coordination axis of the catenae (with a value of 5.0–5.2 Å). Moreover, the paddle-wheels (discs) show tilt angles ranging from 25.5° to 30.6°, and the same thickness (4.52 ± 0.07 Å), calculated for all the known compounds in their polymorphic phase (see ).

elements.content: Polymorph A has a triclinic unit cell (space group P1̅) and shows a lamellar arrangement of same-oriented 1D catenae, which grow in the plane of the carboxylate with the all-trans alkyl chain. There is a characteristic angle between the axes of both alkyl chains with respect to the perpendicular plane of the Cu–O catenae of about 20–25°, depending on the compounds. Members from Cu­(C3)2 to Cu­(C10)2 show this polymorphic phase. The structure of Cu­(C9)2-A is shown in Figure .

elements.content: Polymorph B presents a structure with interdigitated same-oriented 1D catenae, in a triclinic unit cell (see Figure ). Unlike polymorph A, these catenae grow in the plane formed by the carboxylate with the gauche effect. The angle between the two alkyl chains is lower (5–15°) than in the previous case. This polymorph has only been solved for Cu­(C8)2 and Cu­(C10)2 but was also detected for Cu­(C12)2 and Cu­(C14)2 (see section ). It is worth noting that the pseudohexagonal packing of the catenae in this polymorph is very similar to the one found in the CDLC phase (which is hexagonal). This resemblance may explain the partial formation of this phase when cooling from the liquid crystal phase.

elements.content: The third polymorph observed in the Cu­(Cn)2 series, C, appears in the members with n ≥ 9 (see Figure ). It presents a monoclinic unit cell (space group C2/c) with four paddle-wheel units in the unit cell (Z = 8). The orientation of the catenae is alternate, as explained in the introduction (see Figures and c), with a lamellar structure, as polymorph A, and growing also in the plane of the all-trans carboxylates. In this case, the angle between the alkyl chains is negligible, and the planes formed by the trans C atoms of the two chains show a herringbone arrangement (internal orientational order), with an angle of about 45°, unlike the other two polymorphs, where those planes are almost parallel (<5°).

In this case, the angle between the alkyl chains is negligible, and the planes formed by the trans C atoms of the two chains show a herringbone arrangement (internal orientational order), with an angle of about 45°, unlike the other two polymorphs, where those planes are almost parallel (<5°).

elements.content: The alkyl chain packing, parallel (polymorph C) and crossed (polymorph A), cause these polymorphs to show different 00l d-spacings, although both are lamellar. Thus, the linear relationship of this spacing with respect to the number of C atoms shows a step from polymorph A to polymorph C (see , section 5). This can be explained by the closer resemblance of polymorph C (longer members) to hydrocarbons: as the number of carbons increases, the lipidic layer becomes more similar to paraffins, where the alkyl chains are parallel to each other and form a herringbone structure (internal orientational order).

elements.content: The structure of Cu­(C10)2 solved by Lomer et al. obtained by the gel diffusion method with silica gel and aqueous solutions of potassium decanoate and copper­(II) sulfate, does not correspond to any of these three polymorphic forms. However, it combines characteristics of the three of them: (a) it is bilayered and presents a triclinic unit cell with a paddle-wheel unit (like A) but significantly different cell parameters; (b) the 1D catenae are formed in the plane with the Cu atoms and the carboxylates with the gauche effect (like B); (c) the axes of the two alkyl chains are parallel to each other (like C), although there is not a herringbone structure in this case. Although many attempts were carried out to obtain this structure, using the mentioned method and recrystallization in other solvents, it has not been possible to get it in this work. However, it is possibly another polymorphic phase of Cu­(C10)2.

Although many attempts were carried out to obtain this structure, using the mentioned method and recrystallization in other solvents, it has not been possible to get it in this work. However, it is possibly another polymorphic phase of Cu(C10)2.

elements.content: The presence of polymorphism makes the thermal behavior of the compounds in this series very complex. Moreover, this polymorphism was proven to be monotropic, because the polymorphs do not show a reversible transition when they convert through an endo-exo effect into another polymorphic form or melt directly to the CDLC phase. Combined XRD and DSC data have allowed studying the stability of the polymorphs and their thermal parameters and characterizing the phases in every thermodynamic and kinetic process. The stable polymorphic forms are found to be A for members with n ≤ 9 and C for n ≥ 10. Polymorph B is metastable for all the compounds that present this phase.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Study. The Endo-Exo Effect

The presence of polymorphism makes the thermal behavior of the compounds in this series very complex. Moreover, this polymorphism was proven to be monotropic, because the polymorphs do not show a reversible transition when they convert through an endo-exo effect into another polymorphic form or melt directly to the CDLC phase. Combined XRD and DSC data have allowed studying the stability of the polymorphs and their thermal parameters and characterizing the phases in every thermodynamic and kinetic process. The stable polymorphic forms are found to be A for members with n ≤ 9 and C for n ≥ 10. Polymorph B is metastable for all the compounds that present this phase.

elements.content: A thorough thermal analysis study, by DSC and TGA, was done on all of the synthesized copper­(II) alkanoate members. In Figure a,b, the DSC thermograms for the first heating of the thermal stable polymorph and second heating (after cooling from the CDLC phase) are shown, respectively. For more details, see (sections 6–8), where tables (Tables SI.5 and SI.6) with all the thermal data of each compound studied and figures of the DSC (pyrolysis, Figure SI.5) and TGA (Figure SI.6) thermograms are shown.

elements.content: The transition temperatures are shown in Figure for all the studied compounds. It is worth noting that all the members of the Cu­(Cn)2 series decompose before reaching the isotropic liquid phase. The pyrolysis temperatures from the mesophase for all the members of the series, was measured by DSC (see , section 6). All of the members present a fusion on heating from a crystal phase to the CDLC phase (at a practically constant temperature for members above n > 8), with the exception of (i) Cu­(C3)2, which simply decomposes directly from the crystal, and (ii) Cu­(C4)2, which is the only member presenting two solid-to-solid enantiotropic transitions.

elements.content: The total enthalpies (Δtotal H) and entropies (Δtotal S) are the sum of those functions in the so-called stepwise melting process (see , section 7, for more details). From these values, the contributions of the CH2 groups to the melting process can be estimated. The calculated CH2 entropic contribution is much lower than the theoretical value. That is, the alkyl chains in the CDLC are not yet completely melted. Thus, the rigid core of the paddle-wheels could include the contiguous C atoms (α, β, ...) to the carboxylate one, still presenting the same conformation as in the crystal.

elements.content: Remarkable differences can be observed in the DSC thermograms for members with n ≥ 8 between the first and the second heatings, as the two peaks observed in the fusion of Cu­(C8)2 and, mainly, the endo–exo effect (n ≥ 9). This clearly points to a difference in the existing (or coexisting) phases or a lower crystallinity between the samples obtained by recrystallization (corresponding to the first heating) and the ones cooled from the melt (2nd heating). In fact, both effects are responsible of the different behavior. Moreover, both effects are also responsible of the depressions in the melting point and in the enthalpy of transition, found in all of the copper­(II) alkanoates with endo–exo effect, which are particle-size dependent (nano- or microsize). This effect had been already studied not only experimentally but also by modeling. A detailed study, particularly for Cu­(C9)2, is shown in the (section 9).
elements.clean_text:
The Endo-Exo Effect

Remarkable differences can be observed in the DSC thermograms for members with n ≥ 8 between the first and the second heatings, as the two peaks observed in the fusion of Cu(C8)2 and, mainly, the endo-exo effect (n ≥ 9). This clearly points to a difference in the existing (or coexisting) phases or a lower crystallinity between the samples obtained by recrystallization (corresponding to the first heating) and the ones cooled from the melt (2nd heating). In fact, both effects are responsible of the different behavior. Moreover, both effects are also responsible of the depressions in the melting point and in the enthalpy of transition, found in all of the copper(II) alkanoates with endo-exo effect, which are particle-size dependent (nano- or microsize). This effect had been already studied not only experimentally but also by modeling. A detailed study, particularly for Cu(C9)2, is shown in the  (section 9).

elements.content: In the case of Cu­(C8)2, the presence of two endothermic peaks in the thermograms corresponds to the fusion of the mixture of polymorphs formed on cooling the samples from the liquid crystal phase, similar to what happens with the samples obtained from recrystallization in benzene (note that polymorph B melts 6 K below the melting point of polymorph A).

elements.content: On the other hand, the nature of the endo–exo effect observed for n ≥ 9 is more intricate. One clear example is the Cu­(C9)2, whose behavior was comparatively analyzed by DSC and XRD (see Figure ). Thus, the crystalline sample obtained by recrystallization (in most of the solvents used) corresponds to polymorph A and shows a fusion in the first heating (i). When cooling from the CDLC phase at 10 K·min–1, the phase shows the same reflections by XRD (same structure) but with much broader peaks, indicating less crystallinity (smaller and more defective crystals). This phase is polymorph A* (ii) and presents an endo–exo effect on heating, which indicates the formation of another polymorph after the melting (endothermic) and crystallization (exothermic) process: polymorph A* melts at a lower temperature than polymorph A due to the lower crystallinity, and the metastable liquid crystal phase formed crystallizes to polymorph C, which melts at a higher temperature. This new polymorphic phase can thus be obtained by holding the temperature at 370.7 K after the endo–exo process (iii) and cooling to RT. After this thermal treatment, polymorph C is obtained. It presents a different structure than the initial phase (see Figure b), and it shows only a fusion to the CDLC phase on heating (iv). FTIR measurements of this polymorph C, for Cu­(C14)2, have been recorded as a function of temperature, and no change in the bands was observed until the CDLC is reached (see ref and for more details).

When cooling from the CDLC phase at 10 K⋅min-1, the phase shows the same reflections by XRD (same structure) but with much broader peaks, indicating less crystallinity (smaller and more defective crystals). This phase is polymorph A* (ii) and presents an endo-exo effect on heating, which indicates the formation of another polymorph after the melting (endothermic) and crystallization (exothermic) process: polymorph A* melts at a lower temperature than polymorph A due to the lower crystallinity, and the metastable liquid crystal phase formed crystallizes to polymorph C, which melts at a higher temperature. This new polymorphic phase can thus be obtained by holding the temperature at 370.7 K after the endo-exo process (iii) and cooling to RT. After this thermal treatment, polymorph C is obtained. It presents a different structure than the initial phase (see Figure b), and it shows only a fusion to the CDLC phase on heating (iv). FTIR measurements of this polymorph C, for Cu(C14)2, have been recorded as a function of temperature, and no change in the bands was observed until the CDLC is reached (see ref  and  for more details).

elements.content: However, the endo–exo effect depends on the phases that are present for a given compound, apart from the thermal treatment and heating rate (due to its kinetic nature). In this sense, the members of the Cu­(Cn)2 series can be sorted into six groups (summarized in Table ), according to the different polymorphs that they present. Moreover, the phase or mixture of phases formed after cooling from the CDLC phase determines the thermal behavior of the compounds.

Polymorphs Observed in the Cu­(C<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>)<sub> <italic toggle="yes">2</italic> </sub> Series, Stable Polymorphs, And Phases and Processes Observed and in the Endo–Exo Effect group I II III IV V VI members n ≤ 7 Cu(C8)2 Cu(C9)2 Cu(C10)2 n = 12, 14 n = 11, 13 and n ≥ 15 polymorphs observed A A, B A, C A, B, C C, B C endo–exo effect A → C A + B → C C + B → C C → C

Stable polymorph in bold.

Phases with low crystallinity.

Scheme of the transformation (in two steps for groups IV and V).

A thorough diffraction study as a function of temperature was carried out to analyze in detail the endo–exo effect, specially in the cases where polymorph B is also present after cooling from the melt. The most complex case occurs for Cu­(C10)2, where the three polymorphs are observed in a second heating. The thermogram and the thermodiffractograms (3D and 2D contour plot) of the second heating of Cu­(C10)2 are shown in Figure a–c. The different processes and phases involved are the following: (1) initially, a mixture of polymorphs A* and B* (both with low crystallinity) is observed; (2) polymorph A* starts to melt, and a rearrangement of polymorph B* is detected; (3) polymorph C starts to crystallize (from A, which disappears completely), and polymorph B is completely ordered until the end of this step, when it starts to melt; (4) polymorph B melts to CDLC, so the coexisting phases are polymorph C and CDLC; (5) the corresponding part of CDLC phase crystallizes to polymorph C; (6) finally, polymorph C melts to liquid crystal.

The thermogram and the thermodiffractograms (3D and 2D contour plot) of the second heating of Cu(C10)2 are shown in Figure a-c. The different processes and phases involved are the following: (1) initially, a mixture of polymorphs A* and B* (both with low crystallinity) is observed; (2) polymorph A* starts to melt, and a rearrangement of polymorph B* is detected; (3) polymorph C starts to crystallize (from A, which disappears completely), and polymorph B is completely ordered until the end of this step, when it starts to melt; (4) polymorph B melts to CDLC, so the coexisting phases are polymorph C and CDLC; (5) the corresponding part of CDLC phase crystallizes to polymorph C; (6) finally, polymorph C melts to liquid crystal.

elements.content: It is worth noting that polymorph B has been only solved for Cu­(C8)2 and Cu­(C10)2, but it has been detected in Cu­(C12)2 and Cu­(C14)2 (group V), after cooling from the CDLC phase. Thus, the presence of this polymorph has been observed in samples obtained by cooling from the CDLC phase, as it shown in Figure , with significantly less amount of this phase for Cu­(C14)2. Their thermograms show a slightly larger endo–exo effect in comparison with those for odd members with long alkyl chains.

elements.content: In groups V and VI, there is no evidence of the existence of polymorph A. A less crystalline form of polymorph C is found instead, from recrystallization in heptane or by cooling from the liquid crystal. The thermal behavior and existing phases for the other groups listed in Table (showing the thermodiffractograms) are explained in the (section 11).

elements.content: The mixture of polymorphs in Cu­(C14)2 was also analyzed by FTIR. At room temperature, the carboxylic region of the infrared spectra of the sample quenched from the CDLC (Figure a) shows a characteristic pattern with the asymmetric and symmetric carboxylate stretching bands centered at 1585 and 1471 cm–1 respectively. When the sample is heated, these bands shift to 1583 and 1467 cm–1 (Figure b), which correspond to the values observed in the crystal of Cu­(C14)2-C (Figure c). The rest of bands present in this region are coincident in the two samples. This fact confirms that the polymorphs present in the quenched Cu­(C14)2 transform into polymorph C after the endo–exo effect.

When the sample is heated, these bands shift to 1583 and 1467 cm-1 (Figure b), which correspond to the values observed in the crystal of Cu(C14)2-C (Figure c). The rest of bands present in this region are coincident in the two samples. This fact confirms that the polymorphs present in the quenched Cu(C14)2 transform into polymorph C after the endo-exo effect.

elements.content: It is very well-known that some linear polymers (e.g., PET, PEN, PS, or textile fibers) present a similar endo–exo effect, which is associated with a glass transition separately at lower temperature or hidden underneath the endo–exo peaks, described in the literature as conformational relaxation–cold crystallization. This glass transition can be detected by modulated DSC. This experiment was carried out for Cu­(C9)2 and Cu­(C14)2 (see , section 9), and no glass transition was detected, observing a melting process instead. In conclusion, the endo–exo effect in the Cu­(Cn)2 series consists of an endothermic reversing fusion of the metastable polymorph or mixture of polymorphs, with low crystallinity (small and defective crystals), followed by an exothermic nonreversing cold crystallization.
elements.clean_text:
Final Considerations on the Nature of the Endo-Exo Effect in Copper(II) Alkanoates

It is very well-known that some linear polymers (e.g., PET, PEN, PS, or textile fibers) present a similar endo-exo effect, which is associated with a glass transition separately at lower temperature or hidden underneath the endo-exo peaks, described in the literature as conformational relaxation-cold crystallization. This glass transition can be detected by modulated DSC. This experiment was carried out for Cu(C9)2 and Cu(C14)2 (see , section 9), and no glass transition was detected, observing a melting process instead. In conclusion, the endo-exo effect in the Cu(Cn)2 series consists of an endothermic reversing fusion of the metastable polymorph or mixture of polymorphs, with low crystallinity (small and defective crystals), followed by an exothermic nonreversing cold crystallization.

elements.content:
In the samples presenting polymorphism, no reversible transition from one polymorph to another has been observed in the same heating. So all the polymorphs observed should be considered monotropic

Hexagonal Columnar Discotic Liquid Crystal Phase (CDLC)

As it has been studied for many years, the Cu­(Cn)2 compounds present a CDLC phase. The paddle-wheel structure is maintained in the CDLC and presents the same bonding lengths as in the crystal phase, as was observed by EXAFS and by PDF analysis. This phase shows a hexagonal arrangement in the column packing, formed by the stacking of paddle-wheels, and where the alkyl chains are melted (disordered) (see Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
In the samples presenting polymorphism, no reversible transition from one polymorph to another has been observed in the same heating. So all the polymorphs observed should be considered monotropic

Hexagonal Columnar Discotic Liquid Crystal Phase (CDLC)

As it has been studied for many years, the Cu(Cn)2 compounds present a CDLC phase. The paddle-wheel structure is maintained in the CDLC and presents the same bonding lengths as in the crystal phase, as was observed by EXAFS and by PDF analysis. This phase shows a hexagonal arrangement in the column packing, formed by the stacking of paddle-wheels, and where the alkyl chains are melted (disordered) (see Figure ).

elements.content: Representation of the structure of the columnar discotic liquid crystal phase (CDLC), showing the molecules and discs (1), hexagonal packing (2), honeycomb domain (3), and developable domain (4). Crystalline domain thickness, H = h × (25–30).
elements.clean_text: 13  Representation of the structure of the columnar discotic liquid crystal phase (CDLC), showing the molecules and discs (1), hexagonal packing (2), honeycomb domain (3), and developable domain (4). Crystalline domain thickness, H = h × (25-30).

elements.content: In the diffraction patterns of the CDLC phase, a diffuse band at 4.50 Å is observed, which corresponds to the c parameter of the hexagonal unit cell (see Figure a). The profile matching of the patterns with a hexagonal cell gave a value for c of 4.49 ± 0.13 Å. The intercolumnar distance D (which corresponds to the a parameter of the hexagonal unit cell) was also calculated from the diffraction profile matching in this phase for all the members of the series. Since the paddle-wheel units are still present in this phase and the discs are perpendicular to the c axis of the hexagonal cell, the stacking period of the columnar mesophase (h), that is, the thickness of the discs formed by the paddle-wheel units in the mesophase, is constant for all the members. Thus, the unit cell volume and, therefore, the area of the hexagons (since h does not vary) show a linear relationship to the number of C atoms, and the value of (dD 2/dn) can be obtained, which is also constant. From this data, h can be estimated, as described in ref (see , section 12, for details). A value of h = 4.41 ± 0.06 Å was thus obtained. This h value is slightly smaller than that calculated by Abied et al. (4.68 Å) but is in fair agreement with the c parameter obtained from the X-ray diffraction data. On the other hand, the disc thickness calculated for the different polymorphic crystals (at RT) presents an average value of 4.52 ± 0.07 Å (see . 12, Table SI.9), which is also similar to the one in the CDLC phase.
elements.clean_text:
Calculation of the Stacking Period of Discs in the CDLC Phase

In the diffraction patterns of the CDLC phase, a diffuse band at 4.50 Å is observed, which corresponds to the c parameter of the hexagonal unit cell (see Figure a). The profile matching of the patterns with a hexagonal cell gave a value for c of 4.49 ± 0.13 Å. The intercolumnar distance D (which corresponds to the a parameter of the hexagonal unit cell) was also calculated from the diffraction profile matching in this phase for all the members of the series. Since the paddle-wheel units are still present in this phase and the discs are perpendicular to the c axis of the hexagonal cell, the stacking period of the columnar mesophase (h), that is, the thickness of the discs formed by the paddle-wheel units in the mesophase, is constant for all the members. Thus, the unit cell volume and, therefore, the area of the hexagons (since h does not vary) show a linear relationship to the number of C atoms, and the value of (dD 2/dn) can be obtained, which is also constant. From this data, h can be estimated, as described in ref  (see , section 12, for details). A value of h = 4.41 ± 0.06 Å was thus obtained. This h value is slightly smaller than that calculated by Abied et al. (4.68 Å) but is in fair agreement with the c parameter obtained from the X-ray diffraction data. On the other hand, the disc thickness calculated for the different polymorphic crystals (at RT) presents an average value of 4.52 ± 0.07 Å (see . 12, Table SI.9), which is also similar to the one in the CDLC phase.

elements.clean_text: 14  (a) Powder pattern of Cu(C15)2 in the CDLC phase (green arrow indicating the diffuse band corresponding to the (001) plane) and (b) SAXS curves for the crystalline and CDLC phases of Cu(C15)2 (blue arrow indicating the presence of a characteristic distance in the CDLC phase).

elements.content: The liquid crystal phase was studied by SAXS, for the first time, in order to explore the low q range and detect characteristic distances larger than that presented on the hexagonal packing. The crystal and the CDLC phase show a different power law in the small-angle scattering curves. Furthermore, a broad peak is only detected in the liquid crystalline phase (see Figure b). The center of the peak is around 0.50 nm–1, which corresponds to a characteristic distance of 12.5 nm (125 Å). A similar peak is observed for all Cu­(Cn)2 series in the CDLC phase (see Figure SI.18, ).
elements.clean_text:
SAXS Measurements in the CDLC Phase

The liquid crystal phase was studied by SAXS, for the first time, in order to explore the low q range and detect characteristic distances larger than that presented on the hexagonal packing. The crystal and the CDLC phase show a different power law in the small-angle scattering curves. Furthermore, a broad peak is only detected in the liquid crystalline phase (see Figure b). The center of the peak is around 0.50 nm-1, which corresponds to a characteristic distance of 12.5 nm (125 Å). A similar peak is observed for all Cu(Cn)2 series in the CDLC phase (see Figure SI.18, ).

elements.content: The peaks of powder pattern in the liquid crystal phase (Figure a) show that the hexagonal structure presents long-range order in the plane of the hexagons and not in the stacking direction of discs (axis c), as in a honeycomb arrangement presented in Figure , part 3. However, it is well-known that the discs are randomly stacked with respect to each other (maintaining the 1D coordination), and the distance of 125 Å could correspond to the range of the liquid crystalline order (H) of these discs (around 25–30 discs, Figure ). The texture in the CDLC observed by optical microscopy consists of developable domains (Figure , part 4), which in fact are honeycomb structures in which the director axis (in this case, the direction of the 1D coordination polymer) is bent and grows in a spiral. The distance (H) has also been observed in the highly concentrated mixtures of the decanoic acid–copper­(II) decanoate phase diagram, where the same developable domains are formed in the CDLC phase (see Figure SI.18, ).

elements.content: The polymorphism in the members of the Cu­(Cn)2 series and the columnar discotic liquid crystal phase have been thoroughly described in this work combining results from several techniques, such as XRD, DSC, FTIR, SAXS, and polarized light microscopy.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The polymorphism in the members of the Cu(Cn)2 series and the columnar discotic liquid crystal phase have been thoroughly described in this work combining results from several techniques, such as XRD, DSC, FTIR, SAXS, and polarized light microscopy.

elements.content: Copper­(II) alkanoates present a common core structure, the paddle-wheel, which extends forming a 1D coordination polymer (catenae). Diverse arrangements of these 1D catenae define the different polymorphic crystal phases. Three of them have been identified (A, B, and C), A for members with n < 10 and C for those with n ≥ 10 being the stable ones. The other polymorphs (A for Cu­(C10)2, B for even members from 8 to 14, and C for Cu­(C9)2) were proven to be monotropic. The crystal structures, most of them previously unknown, have been solved here by HRPD. Different methods were used to prepare the different phases (recrystallization in different solvents and thermal treatment).
elements.clean_text: Copper(II) alkanoates present a common core structure, the paddle-wheel, which extends forming a 1D coordination polymer (catenae). Diverse arrangements of these 1D catenae define the different polymorphic crystal phases. Three of them have been identified (A, B, and C), A for members with n < 10 and C for those with n ≥ 10 being the stable ones. The other polymorphs (A for Cu(C10)2, B for even members from 8 to 14, and C for Cu(C9)2) were proven to be monotropic. The crystal structures, most of them previously unknown, have been solved here by HRPD. Different methods were used to prepare the different phases (recrystallization in different solvents and thermal treatment).

elements.content: Due to its monotropic nature, the thermal behavior of the different polymorphic forms is very complex, and in fact, they present an endo–exo effect on heating, explained here for the first time and consisting of the fusion of a low-crystalline polymorph or mixture of polymorphs (endothermic and reversing effect), and a subsequent cold crystallization into polymorph C (exothermic and nonreversing effect).
elements.clean_text: Due to its monotropic nature, the thermal behavior of the different polymorphic forms is very complex, and in fact, they present an endo-exo effect on heating, explained here for the first time and consisting of the fusion of a low-crystalline polymorph or mixture of polymorphs (endothermic and reversing effect), and a subsequent cold crystallization into polymorph C (exothermic and nonreversing effect).

elements.content: On the other hand, new studies have been carried out in the CDLC phase to provide a detailed structural characterization of it. The stacking period of the paddle-wheels within a catena presents a value of 4.5 Å, similar to the thickness of the discs in the different polymorphic phases. These discs stack in the c axis forming columns (catenae), which present a hexagonal crystalline order, with a characteristic size of about 25–30 discs (from the data obtained by PXRD and SAXS). This result is in agreement with the fact that the director axis (in the direction of the columns) of the honeycomb structure grows bent to form the developable domains observed by optical microscopy, and well-known in the discotic liquid crystals.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, new studies have been carried out in the CDLC phase to provide a detailed structural characterization of it. The stacking period of the paddle-wheels within a catena presents a value of 4.5 Å, similar to the thickness of the discs in the different polymorphic phases. These discs stack in the c axis forming columns (catenae), which present a hexagonal crystalline order, with a characteristic size of about 25-30 discs (from the data obtained by PXRD and SAXS). This result is in agreement with the fact that the director axis (in the direction of the columns) of the honeycomb structure grows bent to form the developable domains observed by optical microscopy, and well-known in the discotic liquid crystals.
